description: From Middle English putten, puten, poten, from Old English putian, *pūtian ("to push, put out"; attested by derivative putung (“pushing, impulse, instigation, urging”)) and potian (“to push, thrust, strike, butt, goad”), both from Proto-Germanic *putōną (“to stick, stab”), which is of uncertain origin. Possibly from Proto-Indo-European *bud- (“to shoot, sprout”), which would make it cognate with Sanskrit बुन्द (bundá, “arrow”), Lithuanian budė, and budis (“mushroom, fungus”). Compare also related Old English pȳtan (“to push, poke, thrust, put out (the eyes)”). Cognate with Dutch poten (“to set, plant”), Danish putte (“to put”), Swedish putta, pötta, potta (“to strike, knock, push gently, shove, put away”), Norwegian putte (“to set, put”), Norwegian pota (“to poke”), Icelandic pota (“to poke”), Dutch peuteren (“to pick, poke around, dig, fiddle with”).

entries.meaning: (business) A right to sell something at a predetermined price.

examples: He bought a January '08 put for Procter and Gamble at 80 to hedge his bet.

entries.meaning: The act of putting; an action; a movement; a thrust; a push.

verbs.description: put (third-person singular simple present puts, present participle putting, simple past put, past participle put or (UK dialectal) putten)

examples: She put her books on the table.

entries.meaning: To bring or set into a certain relation, state or condition.
examples: He is putting all his energy into this one task.
She tends to put herself in dangerous situations.
He got out of his Procter and Gamble bet by putting his shares at 80.

entries.meaning: To express something in a certain manner.
examples: When you put it that way, I guess I can see your point.

entries.meaning: (athletics) To throw a heavy iron ball, as a sport. (See shot put. Do not confuse with putt.)
To steer; to direct one's course; to go.
examples: His fury thus appeased, he puts to land.

entries.meaning: To play a card or a hand in the game called put.
To attach or attribute; to assign.
examples: to put a wrong construction on an act or expression

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To lay down; to give up; to surrender.
examples: No man hath more love than this, that a man put his life for his friends.

entries.meaning: To set before one for judgment, acceptance, or rejection; to bring to the attention.
examples: to put a question; to put a case

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To incite; to entice; to urge; to constrain; to oblige.
examples: These wretches put us upon all mischief.

entries.meaning: (mining) To convey coal in the mine, as for example from the working to the tramway.

description: Unknown. Perhaps related to Welsh pwt, itself possibly borrowed from English butt (“stub, thicker end”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A fellow, especially an eccentric or elderly one; a duffer.
examples: Queer Country-puts extol Queen Bess's reign,
